Below is a **worked‑out “back‑of‑the‑envelope” case study** that turns the abstract “deaths per TWh” numbers into a concrete, ten‑year estimate for two hypothetical cities that obtain **all of their electricity from a single source** – one coal‑fired, one nuclear‑fission.  

The purpose is to illustrate the *order of magnitude* difference that the published life‑cycle mortality rates imply.  The numbers are **not predictions of what will actually happen**; they are simply the product of a few transparent assumptions and the best‑available average mortality coefficients that the scientific literature reports.

---

## 1.  Defining the two “typical” cities  

| Parameter | Coal‑city | Nuclear‑city |
|-----------|-----------|--------------|
| **Population** | 1 million people (≈ mid‑size metropolitan area) | 1 million people (same size for a fair comparison) |
| **Annual electricity demand** | 5 TWh / yr (≈ 5 kWh person⁻¹ day⁻¹, a realistic figure for a modern city that mixes residential, commercial and light‑industry loads) | 5 TWh / yr (identical demand; the source changes, not the demand) |
| **Time horizon** | 10 years | 10 years |
| **Total electricity generated over 10 yr** | 5 TWh × 10 = 50 TWh | 5 TWh × 10 = 50 TWh |
| **Life‑cycle death coefficient used** | **24 deaths / TWh** (mid‑point of the most‑cited range 8 – 70; this value is the “global‑average, including air‑pollution and mining accidents” used by the IPCC and WHO) | **0.05 deaths / TWh** (mid‑point of the range 0.02 – 0.07; this is the figure most often quoted by the World Nuclear Association and recent peer‑reviewed studies that include routine operation plus the statistical cancer burden from Chernobyl/Fukushima) |

> **Why these coefficients?**  
> *Coal*: 24 deaths/TWh captures the dominant contribution of fine‑particulate (PM₂.₅) air‑pollution mortality (≈ 20 deaths/TWh) plus mining/occupational accidents (≈ 2 deaths/TWh) and a very small tail from rare catastrophic events.  
> *Nuclear*: 0.05 deaths/TWh is essentially the sum of (i) ~0.005 deaths/TWh from routine low‑level radiation releases (well below natural background) and (ii) ~0.045 deaths/TWh that represent the *statistical* excess cancer burden attributed to the two major accidents (Chernobyl and Fukushima) when those burdens are spread over the total electricity generated by the world’s nuclear fleet.

---

## 2.  Calculating the ten‑year death totals  

### 2.1 Coal‑powered city  

\[
\text{Deaths}_{\text{coal}} = \underbrace{24\ \frac{\text{deaths}}{\text{TWh}}}_{\text{life‑cycle coefficient}} \times \underbrace{50\ \text{TWh}}_{\text{10‑yr electricity}} = 1{,}200\ \text{deaths}
\]

### 2.2 Nuclear‑powered city  

\[
\text{Deaths}_{\text{nuclear}} = 0.05\ \frac{\text{deaths}}{\text{TWh}} \times 50\ \text{TWh} = 2.5\ \text{deaths}
\]

Because “deaths” are a discrete outcome, we would round the nuclear estimate to **2–3 expected deaths** over the decade.
